This game continues the Tiberian Sun story arc and is a direct sequel to Tiberian Sun & its expansion Tiberian Sun: Firestorm.Following the franchise tradition, this title follows the story of the almost never ending conflict between the Global Defense Initiative (GDI) and an international paramilitary / militant religious organization called the Brotherhood of Nod. Unlike its predecessors however, this game introduces a new faction in an effort by EA to add more gameplay diversity. The new faction is known as the Scrin.PROS:+ The game has good art style and graphics: (Both of which aged really well specially since this game was released back in 2008.)+ Very good Sound design and unit voice acting.+ Quality live action cinematic played by very well known Hollywood stars and the ever iconic Joseph D. Kucan as “Kane.”+ Lengthy Campaign for each of the factions (about 20 hours if you play them in the Very Hard difficulty setting)+ Great story that is interwoven with each faction (meaning that each faction “wins” in their own right)+ New Faction that is fun to play and comes with an unlockable Campaign once you finish both GDI and NOD campaigns.+ Old factions (GDI and NOD) has been revamped with new units and playstyles without deviating from their respective origin stories.+ Fast paced and intense action.+ Lore heavy with story continuity from the old games.+ Fun and challenging missions during the campaign.+ Revamped game mechanics such as squad based infantry, super unit capture etc.CONS:- No online multiplayer due to GameSpy shutdown: FIX[cnc-online.net]- Some unit pathfinding quirks- Some balance issues (specially with the super units)- Relatively small maps- Limited tech-tree options and build orders- Campaign strategic options has no real effect- Random difficulty spikes between the campaign missionsNEUTRAL+/- Mission objectives are immediately marked in the map thus depriving the player of map exploration. A.K.A. spoon feeding the player enemy locations.CONCLUSION:GREAT GAME that captures the fun and excitement of the old C&C games while adding its own modern ideas to mix thus making for a wonderful and action packed RTS experience.WORTH IT?The game at full price is $15 (or your regional equivalent) thus its a must have for RTS fans and Command & Conquer fans a like. 												I have long been a Command & Conquer fan, starting with Command & Conquer: Red Alert as one of the first PC games I experienced and have since loved to this day. I will side with many others in appreciation of what Command & Conquer 3 accomplished; a return to its roots from the brief transitional period of Generals and stupendous execution of it, at that.Command & Conquer 3, as such, uses a far different method of base construction and economy as compared to traditional real-time strategy games; rather than workers, it relies on the construction yard as both the player's nerve center and primary construction unit. Buildings can be placed in control zones after they have been fully purchased, and are instantly constructed when placed. The player's economy functions through tiberium harvesters, which comb through a field of radioactive crystals rather than attaching themselves to a resource node. For 2007, even though it recalled much of older times in the RTS genre, it was quite a unique game.Gameplay-wise, Command & Conquer 3 is a frantic game of hard counters. Anti-tank troops will rarely be able to take on rifle squads alone, and machine gun turrets will lose handily to main battle tanks. Units can vanish in the blink of an eye without warning, be it from high-potency artillery or sniper ambushes on isolated units. Economy plays a central role, as well; the player who establishes a powerful economy quickly and staunchly will often be the victor, as Command & Conquer games have never featured a supply cap or need for supply structures.For some, this can be a headache. The leading role of economy, knowing troops will often die even with your keenest intervention, and the balancing act of fending off enemy counters in such a fast-paced environment leaves little room for the overly thorough in high-stakes games. Even a strong commander will find themselves in an unenviable position should they lose the economy war, as the frustration of losing harvesters on a stressed budget and watching one's veteran units dwindle with each skirmish can hardly be called a calming state of affairs. Some consider the workerless method of base construction to be backwards and that the over-reliance on economy to decide games is detrimental to the skill involved in playing the game.In terms of storyline, Command & Conquer has always managed to captivate me. It may be nostalgia ballooning the series' writing and acting beyond what it should be, but the plot surrounding the intricate game of cat-and-mouse between GDI and Kane, the corruption of the planet by tiberium (most pointedly, the chilling depictions of red zones), and the live action cutscenes have all served to inspire me on many different levels. Command & Conquer 3's introduction of the Visitors and Kane's prophecy of their arrival have all served to bolster my apprecation of the storyline - C&C4 kept firmly out of mind.While it is unfortunate that Frank Klepacki did not return to grant C&C3 a score similar to the stupendous soundtracks of Red Alert 2 and prior, Steve Jablonsky and Trevor Morris lived up to his quality - if not necessarily style - and brought quality music to the title. Voice acting is more a toss-up, however; while most units offer fitting and well-acted lines, some - most notably Nod's two early scouting vehicles - are overacted to the verge of ridiculousness. Acting, while somewhat overdone in some areas, is enjoyable and mostly believable, and Joseph Kucan's applaudable return as Kane once more can hardly go without notice.Graphics and general sound quality are another toss-up, however. The SAGE engine - used originally for Generals in 2004 - was dated by 2007 standards, especially compared with the Essence engine used by Relic Entertainment in Company of Heroes a year prior. While effects and asset quality are undoubtedly good for their time, the SAGE engine often struggles to keep up, and some oddities can occur from certain situations. Notably, infantry cycling through "take cover" shouts on death and strangeness surrounding some explosion effects, such as the ion cannon strike. Audio, on the other hand, sports some noticeable stock sound effects, but is otherwise well-delivered and masterfully crafted for the various atmospheres in the game.Overall, a dedicated real-time strategy gamer could easily find joy in Tiberium Wars, and a dedicated Command & Conquer follower would be mental to let it slip from their library. With mod support aplenty (if not necessarily as accessible as previous C&C titles) and an official map editor freely available, it is hard to say that minor slights could prevent this game from earning its price and thensome.

												Edit :- All Online Features of this Game are no Longer in Service.Edit :- Working in Windows 10.If you're a fan of the Command & Conquer series, three small words are bound to get you excited: Kane is back. Indeed, so are a good number of beloved series hallmarks, like a huge amount of full-motion video and intense strategic combat. But Tiberium Wars is a lot more than just lip service to franchise enthusiasts, and you don't need the rose-hued glasses of nostalgia to appreciate its polish and intensity. It's simply a superb game that's fun and exciting to play both online and off.The missions themselves are incredibly varied and involve a lot more than destroying an enemy base or defending a particular structure. You'll have to do these things, of course, but you have both primary and secondary objectives to complete, which include using engineers to capture certain buildings, amassing beam cannons to take out defenses, or teaming up with your sworn enemy to defend against alien attack. You'll be doing it all in a variety of real-world theaters, such as Washington, DC, downtown Sydney, and the eerily dry Amazon basin. The near-future take on familiar locales makes the intense battles feel even more thrilling, because the settings are recognizable and meaningful.That's not to say the combat isn't gripping on its own. If you're usually content to turtle up in real-time strategy games, you're in for a surprise: Battles are intense and focused, and they give you little time to prepare. Like any RTS, you still need to build up resources, but it's a quick process of plopping down a bunch of tiberium refineries and power generators and finding the action, because if you don't, the action will quickly find you. Once you get past the first two acts of each campaign, you'll discover that Tiberium Wars' artificial intelligence is aggressive and resourceful, and it will take advantage of your strategic flaws. Don't expect to put your trust in one or two favored units, because even the most powerful units have noticeable weaknesses.It's a rusher's paradise, but you shouldn't take it to mean that technological advancement and thoughtful strategy don't have their places. You won't need to deal with long, complex tech trees, and it makes Tiberium Wars feel somewhat limited in this aspect next to advancement-focused strategy games like Supreme Commander. However, you do have multiple powers and upgrades to earn by building various structures. The powers run the gamut from GDI's powerful ion strike to Nod's vapor bomb, and they fit each faction perfectly. As you use units they level up, making them more effective in battle, and in some cases you improve units by more unconventional means. For example, you can use a Nod warmech to destroy your own flame tank, and the mech will then spew fire in addition to its own native attack.How differently each faction plays is impressive, especially with the new Scrin faction added to the mix. GDI units tend to be straightforward and powerful, and a huge force of mammoth tanks and juggernauts is a challenge to counter. Nod relies on sneakiness and smart use of unique abilities, and a small force of stealth tanks and viper bombers can cripple an enemy's economy. But playing as the Scrin is Tiberium Wars' greatest delight and challenge, since the alien faction is so different from the others. Your first encounters with the Scrin in the campaign are breathtaking, since even low-level units like buzzers look interesting and intimidating. In fact, the most threatening sight within the game is a fleet of Scrin assault carriers and their accompanying fighters. Yet while the Scrin have some potent units and other advantages, such as the ability to collect endless tiberium without building silos, they require a lot of micromanagement and intimate knowledge of each unit and structure.Regardless of your history with Kane and his cohorts, Command & Conquer 3: Tiberium Wars is one of the finest real-time strategy games in years. It's also a triumphant return to form for the series, because it's more than just a graphical update--it's an exciting, well-tuned experience with enough that's old and enough that's new to thrill old-timers and newcomers alike. Suffice it to say, you should play this game, and expect to be playing it for a long time to come.

I had this game on disk since it first came out, and honestly, its had more time put into it than any of my other strategy games put together.When Westwood still existed the C&C series always were wonderful to play - There was just that touch of polish and care which went into their games that you didn't quite get with others, even right down to the little animations of the commandos lighting a cigerrette and chucking it aside, quoting one of their infamous lines with a chuckle. So for 2D units  you were commanding quite a colourful and unique army.However when C&C3 came along... Oohh boy, that jump into 3D. It brought fresh life to the series!... too bad it was the last 'good' game beyond Red Alert 3 after that. EA had washed everything 'Westwood' down the drain.As always the three factions are almost brilliantly balanced; They each have strengths and flaws which play a triangular role against one another, with similar but unique powers and tech trees. While they can be infamous for certain reasons - Scrin with their hordes of alien ships for example - there is no reason why a player cannot use either GDI or NOD to the same extent and counter it. From the previous two games the missions are also once again varied, can last you a while, and the AI can be dubious when you're unprepared (if not a little clumsy here or there) which means you can get quite a few hours out of Skirmish mode.-- Edit --Unfortunately however these days the game's multiplayer has all but dissolved. I think there is still a small community and you might still be able to play matches, though its rare and you're going to have to go out and find it. Despite this I still enjoy playing the game and its Kanes Wrath expansion as a time waster and fond memory of the good times I had with it.--Like I said. Sad to see its the last 'good' game of the series.Command & Conquer 4 'Twilight' ruined the finale to the story by ripping out the core gameplay mechanics, making maps capture-the-flag esque and point control, while plummeting the player into a final 'thats all folks!' with the ending.If you want a true C&C game, get Tiberum Dawn or Sun. If you want an enjoyable 3d C&C game, get this, or Red Alert 3.

												Command and Conquer 3: Tiberium wars is one of my favorite games of my childhood and still continues on 8 years later into my adulthood. Being the first and best RTS games I ever played (originally I played it on Xbox 360 first as the demo when it came out and later the full copy). Here is why it's awesome. The Single Player Campaign (SPOILERS): This game has some fun RTS gameplay and a awesome story that has continued the Tiberium universe in this epic story from the GDI, NOD and Scrin sides. The story culminates into one arch with Kane's goal of Ascension, GDI's goal of stopping tiberium and the new faction the Scrin to take tiberium from Earth. As you play, you get high-quality cut-scenes. EA did a very good job of putting a good budget for the cut-scenes qualities and actors. Notable actors that play in the stories characters are Michael Ironside as Jack Granger, Jennifer Morrison as Kirce James and of course Joe Kucan as Kane. The high-production quality of the cut-scene alone is a damn good reason to play the campaign. The missions on the other hand though are...FANTASTIC! Great missions both challenging and interesting in their own ways. Most of them can be beat though through simple strategies (such as spam), others are very hard and require tactics and strategies to complete the objective. The intel you get throughout the campaign is quite fun to collect and read (you get the intel through completing the missions main and bonus objectives). Other notable things about the campaign that I enjoy is the small "Establishing Video Uplink" in-game cutscenes in the top right-hand corner uplink feel like you're actually being talked to while you prepare for battle. Ultimately outside of the great acting, lore and missions the game has a unique universe that makes it great for the players as you shape it as you play through this fun and amazing campaign. Skirmish and Multiplayer: The skirmish and multiplayer for this game is quite fun. This is the 2nd primary reason you should get this game. Battling against enemy AI's is quite fun when you are alone and then going to multiplayer to survive against a brutal AI with friends is VERY fun. Battling against each-other is very enjoyable and requires skills either out-tech your opponent quickly (if you are GDI) or out-maneuver them through stealth and hit and run tactics as NOD. For the Scrin, simple air spam. (xD) The games can last for around 30 minutes to a hour at most depending on the AI you are going against or player. Other things to note is the lack of official servers for Tiberium Wars, I suggest using evolve or C&C Online if you plan to play with friends or regular players. Overall, its a great time to slug it out and annihilate each other in a war to end all wars game. Maps, Graphics and Performance: This games map designs and graphics blend beautifully to make a wonderful looking tiberium-infested world. From battling in Egypt to Small Town USA, their are many maps types and many ways you can use these maps to your advantage for your faction. On maps you will notice Tech buildings. The different type of tech buildings are... -Tiberium spike Provides an initial bonus and then a constant stream of funds.-Mutant hovel Allows recruiting of Mutant Marauders.-Expansion Point Provides additional ground control.-Subway Hub Provides control over Subway entrances.-Subway Entrance Allow infantry to transfer between entrances.-Tiberium silo Provides a one-time bonus to the first player who captures it.-Reinforcement bay Provides reinforcements.(Campaign only)-EMP control center Allows the launch of an Electromagnetic Pulse at regular intervals. As such straight from the cnc.wiki, the tech buildings allow a side to get a advantage over the other with these buildings using a engineer. They are pretty straight forward as the descriptions say above. But to continue with the graphics, the game looks fantastic. Maxing out all the settings and looking at the eye candy that comes aftward while building your base or leveling someone else's' is quite beautiful. The fidelity and visuals make the game look very wonderful compared to its previous title (Tiberium Sun) and allow the player to have visually stimulating good time. Performance wise, this game runs pretty good. 30 frame cap can be a issue for some, but it rarely dips below that while in-game as battles are usually short and decisive. If you have a decent computer (with at least 8 gigs of ram, a GTX750 or a AMD R7, you will be fine). If you have a gaming computer, prepare for max graphic and no lag. (Outside of that stupid frame cap) Mods: The modding community has kept this game alive and well for many years since its release. With mods that bring back old Tiberium Sun units and Structures or do crazy stuff with Chuck Norris, you will enjoy playing the mods made by the Community. But to be more specific, I will list the categories and links to the mods I most enjoy and you should check out! (Total Conversation)Tiberium Esssense: http://www.moddb.com/mods/tiberium-essence(Total Conversation) CNC Fallout: http://www.moddb.com/mods/cnc-fallout (Crazy) The Chuck Norris Experience: http://www.moddb.com/mods/cc3-the-chuck-norris-experience(Total Conversation) Tiberian Sun Redux: http://www.moddb.com/mods/tiberian-sun(New Faction) The Forgotten: http://www.moddb.com/mods/cc-3-the-forgotten(Total Converstion) Command and Conquer: Tiberian History: http://www.moddb.com/mods/command-conquer-tiberian-history(Total Conversation) Dune: http://www.moddb.com/mods/dark2113(Total Conversation) Halo: Evoultions: http://www.moddb.com/mods/halo-evolutionsWhat I really enjoy about this Modding community is the amount of successful and awesome total conversation mods that bring back many old units from previous games and make them better with the newer engine. I also enjoy the mods that bring in other universes to the engine. My favorite of all of those has to be Tiberium Essence (Sorry Chuck) as it brings some wonderful units and buildings from Tiberian Sun. The mod also does well of improving some of the Units such as the Mammoth Mk2, as its Rocket Pods and Gun turret now actually function and are effective in battle. Also a upgrade on it allows either duel grande launcher turret (to kill enemy infantry in buildings more effectively or clear buildings of enemy infantry) or a Anti-Aircraft duel-railgun turret for shooting down most aircraft with ease. I also been following the mod for years and it has a wonderful developer, community and always more content on the way! The next update will contain The forgotten Faction (Also sorry Forgotten Mod). To get off my box now on my favorite mod, please check out all those mods their, to install a mod and get it to work on steam, make sure you create a Mod folder in Command and Conquer 3 Tiberium Wars folder that should be found in My Documents (You should also see another folder called replays, if you see that, your in the right place). Make sure [Mods] is spelled exactly like that without the brackets. After you make the mod folder, throw the mod into the Mods folder (make sure you have winrar to extract the mod, most mods use a rar file) and then go to your steam library. Right click on Command and Conquer 3 Tiberium Wars in your Steam Library, click Properties, make sure your in the GENERAL tab and click on Set Launch Options. You should see a box come up with a blank text box. Type in the text box [-ui] (without brackets). (DASH_SPACE_LOWERCASEUI)Now the Game browser will appear! Select a mod & play! Overall, Command and Conquer 3: Tiberium Wars is a great game. Fantastic single player campaigns, great skirmish and multiplayer modes, wonderful maps, graphics and good performance. I Highly recommended it if you are a true RTS fan and honestly, this is the last best Command and Conquer game (including Kane's Wrath).

												With 200+ hours on this account for this game; I'll make it quicker than I want it to be and I'll be providing a TL;DR at the bottom.This game is beautiful. No, not just because of the graphics since that does not make a game great. I'll admit that being made in 2007: the graphics do hold very well to this very day. I'm talking about how the game feels to play, how much lore that you can unfold in this game and a very important point I will bring up later on.The game itself is very easy to pick up and learn the basics such as what units do what, what your base does and many other things. As you progress through the story; you'll meet bonus objectives that you can complete for a different medal at the end (great for you completionists). The campaigns can have some very challenging moments for newer players but it will make you do what you're supposed to do: Come up with a strategy to win.Notice that I said campaigns. You can play the GDI (Global Defense Initiative), NOD campaign and a short Scrin campaign. The last being unlocked once you have completed both of the other two campaigns.This game supports free building (allowing you to build almost anywhere on the map except impassable terrain), there is no unit limit and there is some decent to good balance in this game.Now, onto that point I mentioned earlier: It's the community. The C&C community has been part of me throughout my childhood and still is. People have constantly pushed out custom maps that have gamemodes for them such as No money, Art of Defense and Comp stomp. Command and Conquer Generals was my introduction to the community but not the series and I'm glad to see how much it has flourished. If you wish to play this game online: Look into C&C Online. It's a community project that provides players to connect to their servers to play online so you can play with your friends or strangers. Downloading and installing custom maps is incredibly easy to do and can provide you more enjoyment in this game.Now, here's another important piece of the community: Mods. There are tonnes of them that bring things from the older games or whatever the team behind the mod wanted. I've played dozens upon dozens of mods and because of that; this game has continued to be something I love to play and relax with. TL;DR: I love this game and if you're wondering that if it is worth your time and money; I hope you do pick this amazing game up. This game has good replayability with custom maps and mods that you can find via Google.Needless to say that this C&C fan will be giving this game a 10/10.

												This is my first review so im glad I picked one of my favorite games to start off with (be warned its long, so if you want to skip to the end it sums up the review) . My hours don't do it justice but rest assured, I had this game for both PS3 and Xbox before buying it once again on Steam (Yes, I loved it that much, also theres no limit on units which is so much better than being capped on consoles). This game will never be RTS game that sets the bar for all other RTS style games, far from it, BUT, this is infact one of the best RTS games around nowadays. Firstly, you get THREE campaigns for three different factions, each with a very unique style. GDI which is basically your standard army relying on highly advanced tech to destroy your enemies *cough* Mammoth tanks OP *cough* . Then there is NOD (All hail Kane!), arguabley the one that takes the most skill, as you are usually going to end up using stealth units or surprise kamikaze runs in order to halt your more advanced enemies. They may not pack the biggest punch, but they have a really mean defense system which is every turtles dream and every player who likes to steamroll's nightmare. Then there is Scrin, take the ships from Stargate Atlantis and Independence day, throw in some Tripods from War of the worlds and some menacing alien-infantry and you have one of the most OP factions in any RTS ever. All campaigns are great and all have replay value, and trust me, when the difficulty is on hard, you will need an act of god to save you for almost every mission. All and all, the campaigns are really good and all are essentially a tutorial in some way for Skirmish mode. Straight to the point, Skirmish mode is your standard Team Deathmatch, you can do anything between 1v1 to 4v4, or if you want to be a god do a 1v7. Now lets talk about the cons. One of the biggest problems in the game is MASSING, in order words, spamming the same unit over and over cause you can't be bothered to use some real strategy and want to steam roll every skirmish or mission. Whether its creating a moving fortress of 20 Mammoth tanks, swarming the skies with 1000 (slight exageration) Venoms or just flat out crucifying everything in your path with some Scrin aircraft or tripods, if you want to mass, this is your game. However, there is an amazing array of different units with different abilities that the AI uses to its full potential and it takes quite a bit of skill to combat it, try to experiment with different units, massing isn't fun. Next con is the difficulty system. Easy is too easy, its a curbstomp and its the setting you'd use to teach your little sibling how to play. Medium/Normal is a step up but after a few games you should be fine although you can't 1v2 or 1v3 against Medium AI's. Then theres Hard/Brutal, whatever hate-induced state the developers were on when they made this setting, they wanted you to lose. Its nearly impossible to take down a Brutal opponent, it took myself and 2 other friends about 40 minutes to kill a Brutal enemy AI, its honestly that hard unless you mass/turtle. If you like a challenge, this is were you get one. I once did two Brutal AI vs myself and five mediums, after 10 minutes three of my allies were dead and we only won cause I turtled and spammed the super weapons.Lastly the multiplayer servers are down, there is some fan-supported servers around but the official ones are down (♥♥♥♥ YOU EA).So heres the summary, if you want a game for really good campaign and endless amounts of fun with Skirmishes, this is worth it. Avoid massing for a real challenge and use the Mothership to wipe out the whole map if you want to end the map with a bang, pun intended.8/10. KANE LIVES.

												One of my favourite games of all time. Not only was it a absolute blast back when it came out it is still one of the best real time strategy games made to date.First of all, the three sided campaign is masterfully made with a great story and fun missions to back it up, it’s not just a campaign you will love the first time around but for many many more playthroughs. The three factions are well balanced, each with their own unique strengths and weakness like GDI’s slow moving but hard punching pace and Nods quick guerrilla war hit and run tactics. This gives each faction a real reason why you should play them and not just a simple reskin with a few different abilities.If you get a few friends the game really shines, from massive wars with brutal AI’s to making the best defended base you can while keeping the enemy locked away on one side of the map its really a blast.It also has a great modding scene! 												Command and Conquer is a legendary franchise that is much beloved by people all over the world. A franchise that unfortunately has remained dormant for some time and most likely will continue to do so. But most of the games contained within it are extremely great, and this one is no exception.C&C 3 takes place in the Tiberium Wars arc that began with the original game. The world has prospered under the control of the GDI. A sort of United Nations military force, that combats terror threats. However, a quasi-religious cult known as the Brotherhood of Nod reappears to try and take control by force. The thing I like the most about Command and Conquer is it feels the closest to present day warfare compared to other RTS games such as Starcraft. It features a very well funded military symbolizing "peace" and "order" against an anarchistic anti authoritarian movement. And the entire conflict revolves around the accumulation of a resource known as Tiberium.This also ties into the general gameplay of the series and this game in particular. In Command and Conquer there aren't any worker units and buildings are queued similar to units. Your units tend to be squads of footsoldiers, tanks, jet fighters and so forth. Even though it is a very sci-fi game with aliens, lazer beams and so forth. It still feels much more down to earth. Infantry units die very quickly to units carrying rifles, but are useless against buildings and vehicles. Wheras vehicles have lots of health and can carry other units but are weak against explosives. It's a game where you have to pay very close attention to what units you're controlling and which ones are attacking which. C&C 3 in particular takes a few cues from other RTS games like Starcraft. It adds an alien race known as the "Scrin". Who have their own unlockable campaign. Although there are very few surprises when playing as the Scrin, they queue their units the same and their buildings are mostly similar. But there are statistical differences to playing it. Which unfortunately only become really prominent at higher levels of play. My favorite aspect of C&C 3 in particular is it's skirmish mode. Specifically how customizeable it is. You can set a particular AI opponent to have different mannerisms. Like you can set an AI opponent to turtle, meaning staying in his base and preferring to not attack. Or you can set an AI opponent to be a rusher, who will attack at the soonest moment. It's one of my favorite RTS games to play exclusively in singleplayer for this reason. Multiplayer is also available however you will need to use third party methods to get connected as it ran on Gamespy which has been shut down.Solid RTS, one of my favorites. Easily recommended if you're a fan of campaign and skirmish.

Posted: March 19, 2014
												1995... A game named Command and Conquer appeared... and paved the way for an entire genre. It's a name that many RTS veterans should be familiar with. The franchise had its ups and downs throughout the years. 2007, the long awaited sequel of Command and Conquer Tiberian Sun appears. Has it passed the test? Let's see...Visually, the game is downright gorgeous, even for today's standards. You can tell at first glance, whether the map is situated in a still pristine Blue zone, a conflict-torn Yellow zone or in an almost unearthly Red zone. The units are also well designed and their appearance alone tells something about the respective faction. Topped off with non-excessive and neat special effects, the visuals give a good impression.Gameplaywise, the game has undergone major changes. Instead of one single build queue, where the amount of respective facilities only determined production speed, now each production facility has its own queue, and units have gained special abilities. These changes were not wellcomed by all fans of the franchise, but I'll allow myself to use a proverb: "I don't know if it's going to be good, but if it is to become better, it must change". Other than that, the "hard-counter" unit-system has finally reached a desireable level, unlike in previous titles, pretty much every unit can be put to a good use and has its weak points. Not every change is good though. The gameplay is kind of too fast-paced compared to its precedetors, and that signifficantly weakened the efficiency of commando-infiltrations, which were the brandmark of this franchise. Command and Conquer 3 lets you deploy a countermeasure in a matter of seconds, leaving little to no room for a classic commando rampage, which was possibly the most fun thing Command and Conquer could offer. That aside, the gameplay gets way more than a passing grade. The audio: The first thing C&C fans will notice that the OST simply doesn't have the same magic as the ones composed by Frank Klepacki. Just thinking of "March to doom" playing as you scrape together leftovers of your army in late-game for a final desperate attempt to win sends chills down my spine. Still, the soundtrack is by no means bad. The sound effects are seamlessly implemented, and is good and bad at the same time. Remember how your hands started sweating when you hear the ominous thundering sound of the allied Cruiser's cannons in Red Alert? It was the sound saying: "say goodbye to your base". On the other hand, with the sound effects not standing out too much, you can keep being fully focused on the events on the battlefield and can clearly make out the very important and helpful announcements of your EVA unit, pointing out upcoming danger.Despite all the flaws pointed out, Command and Conquer 3 Tiberian Wars is a very enjoyable game and I recommend it to both newcommers and veterans. Verdict: 8.5/10

Content:There are many great maps from basic trainings to precision timings in the campaign. There are also skirmish maps that can be used for the multiplayer mode or practicing your skill with AI. The units in the game has a lot of different variety from infantries, vehicles, and aircrafts. These units are also splited into 3 different factions with different play style. Overall, the content for campaign is great if you compare with the expansion pack (Command and Conquer 3: Kane's wrath), but the units varies a lot more in the expansion pack. I forgot to mention that there are custom maps and mods in the game too.Quality:Can't say a lot of things about this, the game was created in 2007 and the expansion 2008. It actually is categorized to be a great quality during those years. For quality about gamplay, the units are balanced and are well executed in the game. Sometimes they might bug out under the map or not following certain commands but it happens quite rare. The quality for the genre RTS fits perfectly.Weaknesses (downsides):- There are no more updates to this game except community updates which are rarely seen. - Multiplayer needs friends that you know since it's impossible to connect randomly to a person. Sequels are dead/ruined (Command and Conquer 4: Tiberian Twilight). - After researching a bit in the game, Brutal AI is somewhat cheating for the economy because of its unstoppable economy even when there are no tiberiums left on his field. But if you are looking for a challenge, this AI is for you. - Not a lot of skirmish maps other than community made maps- Problems with certain OS like windows 10, windows 8.1, ectThe Conclusion:This game was made about 10 years ago, so it's not perfect and even games these days are not perfect. The price is really not that worth it, I recommend you to wait for sale. The game, based on what I see, is rated 9/10.Some stuffs:- The campaign can be really challenging in hard mode- There is a level editor for the game, unfortunately steam version has some problems with it. There is a fix but I'm not sure if it works for all users- There is a fix to the crashing problems in on windows 10 and other stuff- The best RTS that I've ever played in my life, might be replaced but this will always be somewhere in my heart :). The game changed the way I think, more strategic certainly.- The expansion pack has a server where you'll be able to go online and play matches with people around the world. It also has tournaments (sometimes/rarely) and some updates.Final bits: I talk about the expansion in this review because it still has potential on reviving the game, but I prefer missions  and co-op (no co-op, just my style) so I write it down here.

												It's a never ending circle. And I'm going to be really honest here.I've enjoyed this game when I was 7 years old and I still do to this day. The game's dynamics, graphics, gameplay and mechanics are amazing. There are so many ways of playing this game, doesn't matter how and what you do. But, of course, you have to think. Think fast and hard. When I'm sitting and have nothing better to do, I start to look at many games in my library. Always repeating the same words over and over again, that I have nothing to play. But seeing how C&C3:TW is just sitting there, begging for me to play it, I start to move my mouse on that "PLAY" button. I press it and get into it for more than an hour, without warning anyone that I'm going to play it, but hey, who cares and/or needs to know? And there I go. Skirmish with bots. You wanna say, that it isn't fun with bots? Wrong, it is. You can basically find and download variants of maps on the internet and try them out. You can try and play against Brutal, Hard and Medium bots, let some of them be your allies and/or enemies. Build up a base with lots of defences so that you won't screw things up and don't lose.Build up an army out of ground support units like the Rifleman Squads, Missile Squads, Predator Tanks etc. That's for GDI. Choose NOD for example: 10 Avatars, 6 OP Stealth Tanks, Beam Cannons and 2 Airfields with 8 Vertigo Bombers. And that is already a good and a powerful army that will kick♥♥♥♥♥ For GDI: 4-6 Mammoth Tanks, 4-6 Predator Tanks, 4 APCs with 2 Rifleman Squads and 2 Missile Squads inside the APCs and 4-8 Firehawks. Both armies will kick each others asses in seconds or minutes. If you're in deep and chosen a map with Tiberium Spikes, never fear. Capture it, build up defences (use a Surveyor for that) and start slowly farming resources from that Tiberium Spike. Yeah, I know, it's a pain in the butt and a very slow process, but you'll have to manage to succeed. What about the Scrins? They're good, but the Mothership for $5000 is too OP, so I don't recommend to use it instantly. Just wait until you start losing and use some air support to let the Mothership destroy just everything. One charge from that cannon and the enemy's base is lost, turned into sheds.I'm that kind of a person who likes to watch the battlefield from above. That's why it's called strategy, obviously (UPDT: No). I saved a lot of replays and I still watch them just to see how tanks, vehicles, air and ground units are turning into minced meat and start drowning into the ground. Seeing how 3 armies fight between each other, fight together against one or two armies, it's just a non-stop gameplay.My grade? I will always keep my solid 10 out of 10 on this game. I can't leave it nor delete it. It's mechanics and gameplay are just addictive, like a drug. The singleplayer campaign has an intresting and a very amazing story, although it's getting harder to beat the game starting from Croatia when playing as NOD or Alexandria as GDI. Strongly recommend.  UPDATE  Thanks to CNC3 World Builder, I can finally bring this game back to life for myself by building maps. And here's a thanks to EA for this. To all those owning this game and those who still think of picking it up, buy it. Buy and play it. You won't regret it. Maybe some day I'll upload my best maps to C&C3 Mod website and make it downloadable for you! Never forget such games, bring them back to life.For Kane!For The Brotherhood of NOD!Peace through Power!Kane lives in death!Kane is the messiah!

content:
Posted: July 14, 2016
												Disclaimer: I primarily played this game with a non steam copy.Jesus, this one brings back some memories. I remember actually being on the forums as this game progressed. I remember some of the EA forum members as well and all the drama that happened both from the forum members and the EA staff, like EAApoc being "kidnapped" by Nod to keep the third faction a secret, thus mysteriously EALAPredator made an appearance to take his place and he totally isn't the same guy behind the username. Regardless, I was too poor at the time to buy the game on release. I got it a bit later when it was $30 to buy the special edition thingy that came both with this and Kane's Wrath. With that said, I hold Command & Conquer series very dear to my heart. Red Alert 2 was probably one of my favorite games of all time for a long time... Hell, it probably still is. However, Command & Conquer Generals was a huge slap in the face to fans of the series. Command & Conquer Generals is a great strategy game, but it's an insult to the C&C fanbase to call Generals a Command & Conquer game, an even bigger insult to claim the whole series connects to Generals somehow (I bet EA doesn't make those claims anymore). EA has a history of not doing Command & Conquer series justice, especially today. I will say that this game, as well Kanes Wrath, is probably the LAST true Command & Conquer game with quality gameplay. The game is great. For any strategy gamer that is unfamiliar with C&C base building, it's simple. You have different factory types, just like any other strategy game, but you do not need any form of constructor unit to build structures. You have a construction yard, you build around the construction yard, you can no longer build structures if you lose said construction yard, etc. All the newer C&C games don't implement this any longer, which is a shame because that is what made this series so special. There is only a small handful that implements RTS in such a way, so it's strange for them to basically change the formula from being unique to being generic. With that ramble nonsense said, this game has proper C&C base building and it works great. It's fluent, it's easy to understand, it's great. What makes this different from the old school C&C games is it implements upgrades in a way similar to C&C Generals, which is great because it's much more flexible and clean unlike the older C&C titles that implements upgrades. The resources gathered in this game comes from a source that is typically never ending, making it necessary to take over strategic points on the battlefield. The maps design that comes with the game is generally well crafted, making it possible to attack enemies by multiple points. The great thing is how many maps you can download from the community using the "World Builder" tool, which is a map editor/creator. The only bad thing is how this game doesn't use workshop like it easily could. The single player campaign is great. It's not too cheesy, it's just good quality B-Movie material. The game has great live action scenes, which the C&C series is famous for, that tell a great story in a creative way. They're not directly telling a story, you are told a story by being given orders and playing the missions. Rarely, there's an exception to this chemistry, but it's a good system that worked well for all the other C&C games and is oddly pretty unique to C&C how it's implemented. Online is dead. However, when it was alive, it was good. You can still play LAN, which I'm sure you're aware can be used through programs like Tunggle or Hamachi. The gameplay is great with other players.The AI in the game is greatly challenging. It's fun to play against both humans and computers alike. Overall, the game is fantastic. Kane's Wrath is a great addon to consider if you enjoyed this one. Pros-Great single playerSimplistic and easy to learn gameplay, but rewarding to masterfast paced, fluent, and the battles are overwhelmingly satisfyinggreat variety in maps, especially with community based mapsCons-Not a whole lot of variety for playable faction choices such as sub factions (this is addressed in Kane's Wrath expansion)Online is dead, you'll have to use LAN$15 is pretty high for a game of this nature and ageReplayability for singleplayer is not overwhelmingly high8/10

												Command and Conquer 3 returns to the GDI vs NOD setup of the original games and adds a third faction. The third faction, the Scrin, is a unique alien force only playable in C&C 3. The gameplay is definitely not as complex as StarCraft 2, and the simpliest strategies usually work. Any stratigy beginner should find alot to work with here, although I personally perfer the nutty Red Alert series to this one. 												Difficulty for campaign is completely unreasonable.  An example: In one of the GDI missions in Sarajevo, you need to build up a force to attack a heavily fortified Nod position.  It's pretty much impenetrable to ground assaults and air attacks.  You can't use the ion cannon on the main objective because it's shielded.  Now, you would think the logical way to handle this would involve a build up of high-tech, high cost units.  But you can't- because you will be blowing all your money on building and repairing base defenses.  Let your base get destroyed, and you won't be able to complete later objectives.  There are no production facilities you can take out easily to slow down enemy waves.  The only defenses of the Nod base that you can destroy with impunity are the obelisks, which are vulnerable to air assault, but will quickly be rebuilt.I eventually assaulted the base with ten mammoth tanks, and managed to destroy less than half of it.  I couldn't do more because my base was destroyed at that point.On all missions, AI will also attack on two or more different fronts, and with such rapid, frequent attacks that even a diehard RTS fan can be overwhelmed.  Also, you can't build walls or gates anymore, because why would anyone want to keep enemy units out of their base easily?  And you can't build in certain locations for no discernible reason, other than the design team said so.This game is designed to be more frustrating than fun.  It is a far cry from Tiberian Sun.  It's a shame that such a game franchise went in this direction- I'm sure it's a great story, it's got famous actors in it, there are great units...but the fact that missions are designed to screw you over every way possible just makes this not worth the time.

												I have been a strategy game player all my life, I and can honesly say this is one of the worst. Sure there are great graphics and the cutscenes that glorify you, the commander, with well known science fiction actresses playing the rolls are certain to make you feel like a conquering hero. But beyond that the gameplay is nearly unplayable unless you are an expert. I was playing on normal up until act 5 when I just got way to tired of having to restart. Because once you make a mistake, there is no recovering. The tiberium crystal economy is always too slow to keep up your war machine with the constant enemy advances. And the worst part of it is that you are basically on a timer. Because once you are out of the initial crystal piles, there is no way to keep up production because the crystal piles grow out of the ground at a slugs pace. On top of that, there seems to be no way to build up defences to use a 'turtle up' strategy, even while you are trying to build up your initial forces. And because of that, enemies are constantly getting inside of your base and wreaking havok on your very weak structures that cost more than an arm and a leg. On top of that, there seems no other way to win than to build up a massive force and then sweep the map. Because there is no real use for scouting and no long range siege abilities except on the absolute most expensive units, when it would be a much better idea just to build up a lot of mammoth tanks. You can forget about skirmishing as the enemy will always either have a large number of base defenses that will wipe out any small force or their troops will be in constant production coming out of their buildings so you wind up doing no real damage and lose everything. I do not recommend this game to anybody, even if you are already bord of all your other games. Stick with the good old Age of Empires or Starcraft series for a much more enjoyable experience.

The game’s OK I guess though I’m really not that good at it.Pros: This game has many different difficulty levels and AI tactical settings allowing for a great deal of replayability, There are two campaigns and a skirmish/simulated multiplayer mode in addition to actual multiplayer possibilities, the graphics are the best I have seen on any RTS tactical game other asides from the Homeworld games and yet the system requirements are relatively low. The game also runs fast. There are 3 playable factions to choose from, the music is adequate at worst and catchy at best, the sound is outstanding, the controls have an easy learning curve and work well. This is definitely a worthy successor to the previous primary command and conquer game (Tiberium Sun) and picks up the story where that game left off. Units and structures are interesting and yet easy to identify (particularly if you are familiar with this kind of game), the game appears to be completely free of any bugs, the game's menus and interfaces are fine and yet for all this...Cons: This game is extremely difficult for a variety of reasons (and therein lies its main failing (or is it mine?). The AI on any setting rated medium or over can be extremely unforgiving of any tactical mistakes (as it appears to make no mistakes itself), the realism and realistic importance of the "tactics" involved in playing this game are questionable at best (and totally nonsensical at worst) as the game almost continually appears to encourage you to take 100 percent losses and attack without having all of your people and vehicles in order (or even constructed). Coordination between different types of vehicles and soldiers is a necessity but such vital elements such as airstrikes and artillery are given an odd, back-seat to the main, ground-based action (which is actually classic, normal gameplay for the Command and Conquer franchise). Air power is stronger in this iteration of the game than in previous Command and Conquer games but is still quite weak, requiring 4 or more aircraft of any type to have much of an affect in any battle (as was still true in past CC games) For all of the game's futuristic appearances, units behave in an oddly World War II styled manner (with similar (or lesser) ranges applying to their weaponry (as was also shown in past CC games), the game still often manages to feel like an elaborate board game throughout (like its predecessors), the environments are interesting and often beautiful but fall under only 3 main categories (alien, war-ravaged desert, and cityscape with some greenery), The main campaigns become extremely frustrating very quickly as they begin to continually (to the extent that the game becomes extremely predictable) place you in situations wherein the enemy has a totally unfair advantage and your own forces are in a state of severe disarray (as in previous CC games). The skirmish maps are perhaps the most fun part of the game but there is unfortunately not a great variety of them and they are often setup in an overly formal manner (it ends up looking sort of like you are having a battle in a war-ravaged formal french garden further adding to the feeling that you are playing a complicated board game). Perhaps the worst part of all this is however, how much raw potential for fun and interest which the game has but doesn't manage to live up to. The tactics in this tactical game rarely make much real-world sense....Or maybe I'm simply not very good at it or the tactical situations may simply be too nonsensical even for my tastes (but I never can seem to gather enough resources fast enough no matter how many refineries I build and regardless of where on the battlefield I build them).A friend of mine who tends to play more strategy/tactical games than I do also once told me he was having a hard time with this game too though...so maybe it's just a really, really hard game.Kane’s Wrath is better in every respect. It’s too bad you have to install this to play Kane’s Wrath.

Note: I have this game on Origin with 335 hours prior to purchasing on Steam. Command & Conquer 3: Tiberium Wars is a worthy addition to the C&C franchise. It runs well and is generally bug-free — though a few irritating bugs are present, such as: sometimes, while in a skirmish game against an AI, stealth is useless. Their units follow your stealthed units around as if the unit was visible.The game butchered the 'tiberian' canon somewhat from the previous games. Originally, 'Tiberium' used to be some sort of organism; a plant that crystalizes minerals from the ground and emits poisonous gases. This entity was sent to the earth by the Scrin to transform Earth into a planet suitable for them. In this game, they completely changed the chemical composition of the entity. Instead of an alive plant-like organism, 'tiberium' is now a crystal that acts like some sort of lifeless radiative substance sent to Earth to crystalize the entire planet for mineral harvestation.Aside from the canon, the storyline is... okay. It's not great, but if stories aren't your thing, it's passable. If you're joining the series without prior C&C experience, the story is not really that interesting.As an RTS title, I would say it is disappointing. Work has gone into balancing and unit design, and generally works, but as a balance system alone, it is pathetic. In order to win, you need less strategy and more tank-rushing. Infantry are almost useless and aircraft aren't far behind.A good point of consideration is the availability of mods, however. There are some mods that add desperately-needed balancing changes to make the game require an actual brain. There are also mods that boost the total hours you are going to get out of this title by converting the game to fit with unique themes, such as: Dune II, Cold War era, modern warfare, etc.ConclusionI would recommend this game only if you have been introduced to the C&C series prior to the release of this title. If were looking at it purely as an RTS, it does okay. You might want to pass it up if your standards are somewhat high. Otherwise, I suggest giving it a try. I love the game.

												Decent game. My only complaints are:EA completeley changed the atmosphere of the game. It went from post-apocalyptic, dramatic and gloomy with some heavy science-fiction elements, to Modern Warfare as an RTS game with aliens. They completely got rid of a lot of aspects that made Tiberian Sun such an atmospheric game, such as map-wide ion storms, tiberium mutants (while they still exist canonically they only rarely make appearances), and NOD was dumbed down greatly in the sense that their technology now sucks pretty badly and their numbers/strength are fairly laughable. You can't have a singleplayer skirmish without the AI spamming grenadiers/black hand/buzzers. Those are the only infantry units that the game's AI will make and it makes it extremely frustrating to employ infantry of your own because those three types of troops clear garrisons and kill infantry instantly.The scrin are OP - it's mostly a matter of how you fight them but considering they get fighters that don't need to re-arm and gunships and frigates and all that and the NOD and GDI only have fighters and some light AA, it's not really fun to go up against them unless you know exactly what you're doing.-Another thing about the Scrin is that all or most of their units get shields. It's like playing against the protoss in Starcraft all over again.Another thing is that defenses suck (unless you play with the old Tiberium Essence mod) - there's no walls and turrets are pretty weak. All in all I'd give it a 7/10 because I loved the previous C&C games and EA did a good job of continuing the story for the Tiberium series, but it is lacking in some areas that could have been executed better.

												Command and Conquer 3: Tiberium Wars is an amazing game set in the alternate timeline in the command and conquer world where Tiberium has been discovered and is eradicating the entire planet as a major military force GDI tries to keep the world at peace and stop the spread of the Tiberium while the Brotherhood of Nod recruits people living in ruined Yellow Zones (areas that while habitable despite Tiberium exposure are very poor and full of strife) to combat GDI and speed up the spread of Tiberium considering it the next chain in humanitys evolution.The graphics in the game are great even when on low but if you've got the graphics card for max settings its a feast for the eyes (for the games time anyways). The tanks look massive and the unique units Nod has like the Avatar are imposing but not impossible to down and watching your super weapon utterly annihilate the enemy base is always visually satisfying be it a nuclear bomb or the Ion Cannon.Sounds as always are good. A tank firing a missle sounds like, well, a tank firing a missle. The music soundtrack is good as well but most times youll be to focused on dealing with an enemy onlsaught to really listen to it.The story is rich and the FMV sequences are great and all feature famous actors such as Micheal Ironside. Theres 3 campaigns as well each telling the story from a different side. The first being the GDI's campaign and the second Brotherhood of Nod campaign but the third campaign (which i wont spoil here) is only unlocked after completing the first two campaigns.Difficulty can range anywhere from cakewalk to seemingly impossible. This is mostly in part to the games latest patch which balances some units more but breaks others. Example would be the Mammoth Tank and Black Hand. The mission the Tank is introduced for you to use is supposed to be an easy one due to it being GDI's best land vehicle but after the patch the tank is not nearly as powerful as it should be which in turn makes the mission a lot tougher. The Black Hand is a flamethrower unit for Nod and being infantry are supposed to be weaker to anti infantry turrets but after the patch not even 3 anti infantry turrents can down one squad of them. Post patch the only effective way to deal with them is either aircraft bombings or attempting to run them over with a tank which they seem to be able to chew up effectively too.Overall Command and Conquer 3 Tiberium Wars is worth the buy along with its expansion pack Kanes Wrath. Its definitely one of the greatest Command and Conquer games out there alongside Command and Conquer Generals. I give C&C TW3 an 8/10.

												(Note; I've played this game for over 250hrs outside of Steam)It's no Tiberian Sun, but it's by no means bad. It's certainly not as horrendous as C&C4 by any stretch, but it could also have been better.I do however have some gripes with this game that I need to mention.- The game varies from the typical image I felt fit GDI and Nod quite well, making Nod more of a religious fanatical force, and GDI more a modern-day military, which sadly seems to be an attempt at mirroring the whole 'middle eastern conflict' that even today stretches on. - The technology seems to have dumbed down; after the Second Tiberium War, a load of units (Titans, Subterannean units, etc) were decommissioned. Most of them are rectified in the expansion, but they were iconic to their factions and logical tech paths for them to have taken; removing them seems rather silly.- The atmosphere is lacking in comparison to its predecessor, Tiberian Sun; the tiberium wastelands sorely lack the same sort of apocalyptic feel that was present in TibSun.- The storyline of CABAL from TibSun: Firestorm seems as though it was completely ditched, which is a little sad.Overall, though, the gameplay is very much solid and even to this day works well. I would recommend it, especially with the Kane's Wrath expansion, and I give it an 8.5/10.

												Command and Conquer 3: Tiberium Wars is an amazing game set in the alternate timeline in the command and conquer world where Tiberium has been discovered and is eradicating the entire planet as a major military force GDI tries to keep the world at peace and stop the spread of the Tiberium while the Brotherhood of Nod recruits people living in ruined Yellow Zones (areas that while habitable despite Tiberium exposure are very poor and full of strife) to combat GDI and speed up the spread of Tiberium considering it the next chain in humanitys evolution.The graphics in the game are great even when on low but if you've got the graphics card for max settings its a feast for the eyes (for the games time anyways). The tanks look massive and the unique units Nod has like the Avatar are imposing but not impossible to down and watching your super weapon utterly annihilate the enemy base is always visually satisfying be it a nuclear bomb or the Ion Cannon.Sounds as always are good. A tank firing a missle sounds like, well, a tank firing a missle. The music soundtrack is good as well but most times youll be to focused on dealing with an enemy onlsaught to really listen to it.The story is rich and the FMV sequences are great and all feature famous actors such as Micheal Ironside. Theres 3 campaigns as well each telling the story from a different side. The first being the GDI's campaign and the second Brotherhood of Nod campaign but the third campaign (which i wont spoil here) is only unlocked after completing the first two campaigns.Difficulty can range anywhere from cakewalk to seemingly impossible. This is mostly in part to the games latest patch which balances some units more but breaks others. Example would be the Mammoth Tank and Black Hand. The mission the Tank is introduced for you to use is supposed to be an easy one due to it being GDI's best land vehicle but after the patch the tank is not nearly as powerful as it should be which in turn makes the mission a lot tougher. The Black Hand is a flamethrower unit for Nod and being infantry are supposed to be weaker to anti infantry turrets but after the patch not even 3 anti infantry turrents can down one squad of them. Post patch the only effective way to deal with them is either aircraft bombings or attempting to run them over with a tank which they seem to be able to chew up effectively too.Overall Command and Conquer 3 Tiberium Wars is worth the buy along with its expansion pack Kanes Wrath. Its definitely one of the greatest Command and Conquer games out there alongside Command and Conquer Generals. I give C&C TW3 an 8/10.
